CTR Kinematics¶

Three main steps:¶

1. Boundary value problem¶

The differential equations can be written as:

\[\ddot{\psi}_{i} = \dfrac{k_{ib}}{k_{it}k_{b}}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{n}k_{jb}\kappa_{i}\kappa_{j}\sin(\psi_{i}-\psi_{j})\]

with the boundary conditions:

\[\psi_{i}(0) = \alpha_{i} - \beta_{i}\dot{\psi}_{i}(0),\]
\[\dot{\psi}_{i}(L_{i}+\beta_{i}) = 0.\]

where the \(\psi\), \(\dot{\psi}\) are the tube angle and tube torsion, \(k_{ib}\) is the bending stiffness of tube \(i\), \(k_{it}\) is the torsional stiffness of tube \(i\), \(\kappa_{i}\) is the curvature if tube i and \(\alpha_{i}\) and \(beta_{i}\) are the joint variables — translation and rotation of tube \(i\).

2. Robot curvature vector¶

The deformed curvature vector of the robot along the robot backbone can be found by:

\[u = K^{-1}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}K_{i}(R_{\psi_i}u_{i}^{*}-\dot{\psi_{i}}e_{3}),\]

where \(K_{i}\) is a \(3\times3\) stiffness tensor of tube \(i\), \(K = \sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{i}\), and \(u_{i}^{*}\) is the pre-curvature vector of tube \(i\).

3. Robot backbone position in 3D-space¶

Two differential equations for reconstructing the backbone position are as follows:

\[\begin{split}\mathbf{\dot{R}} = \mathbf{R}\mathbf{\hat{u}},\\\end{split}\]
\[\mathbf{\dot{p}} = \mathbf{R}\mathbf{e}_{3},\]

Reference¶

D. C. Rucker, R. J. Webster III, G. S. Chirikjian, and N. J. Cowan,“Equilibrium conformations of concentric-tube continuum robots, ”TheInternational journal of robotics research, vol. 29, no. 10, pp. 1263–1280, 2010
